Patch Set 16:

(1 comment)
Still failing the build

I've been learning how to use a local copy of the CI to fix the code-format errors, and hopefully my latest upload will go through.

Thanks for the help the other day with getting the CI to check my changes after I (guess?) I stalled it out, BTW! 👍 

I assume the 'stall' happened because I rebased my code to master on my machine, then pushed the amend to Gerrit while this review was marked as "work in progress." I changed the review status back to 'active' after uploading, but seems like the CI wasn't checking the code when I did things that way. 

Am I right to think that you fixed the issue just by running 'rebase' to Master from the Gerrit page here?
Add the file to meson build?
Will do!
nit: this seems too generic for a name
Good point. That field's value is a holdover from old internal code. I'll change it to 'DL360 G10 POC server'
Done
Is this a FRU property?

You are correct. 

In builds from HPE's internal repo, PCA_PART_NUMBER is a property of FruDevice/HPE. FruDevice/HPE properties aren't available in mainstream OBMC at this time, but should be in the future.
Done
LGTM, leave it up for couple more days to see if there is more comment

Should I ask around in the Discord about advancing this Gerrit review (perhaps in the 'development' channel?), or is there somewhere else you would recommend I check?

Thanks for the help on this so far!

The DL360 config file now uses type:HPEFan instead of Type:GxpFan to match with existing naming conventions. This change is also reflected in the dbus-sensor code that keys off this field.

Change disussion can be found here:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/62008/6..8/src/FanMain.cpp#b45
I don't think the commit message needs to mention this.
Ack
Please add tested section
Ack
No Tachs?
Correct. There is no tachometer on these fans.
Sorry missed this one.
To be clear, these are PCIe sensors on the physical mainboard, or on a riser?  If they're on a riser, they need put in their own EM config file.
Generally, the PCI Zone temperatures on HPE platforms are on the mainboard near the PCI slots. I'll definitely keep your comment in mind when we start on option card support.

This type doesn't exist that I can find in the project.  Please remove this config stanza until after the dbus sensors thing is in place.  I really suspect this is going to be specified to be something like "BMC temp" as a generalized, non-SOC specific type, because the SOC type doesn't matter in this context.
Ack
You have a fan with no Tachs?
Correct- no tachs on these fans.

This is going to be a type that's specific to the SOC, so GXEFan, although we really should make that generic at some point.

Again, I don't see implementations of HPEFan anywhere, so please remove until those are done.

Discussion of HPEFan vs GXPFan naming: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/62008/comment/2351bc99_196a3d8f/

If you think we should change it to GXPFan, I can submit a new gerrit change to dbus-sensors for further discussion there.
SERVER_ID doesn't match any IPMI formatted FRU fields, which would lead me to beleive this needs to be put in an HPE specific interface namespace.

Thanks for the suggestion- an update to the design doc for detecting HW with no FRU (data passing through uBoot): 

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/65678/5/designs/no-fru-device-hw-detect.md#90

now talks about using a '.FruDeviceAlternative' namespace (final name *very* up for discussion)
Same thing here.  PCA_PART_NUMBER isn't in the FRU device interface.  This would be in an HP specific API, or more than likely mapped to the appropriate fru device fields.
Ack
All systems have an asset tag of 001?  I'm almost certain this is wrong?

I'm going to have to ask around about this. This particular line is an old holdover from a proof of concept implementation, and can probably be removed for now. 

This gerrit review already has a +2, but is blocked by a merge conflict-  so I'm going to make some changes you've suggested like removing the GXPSensor stanza for now, then submit an --amend and wait for a new +2 review.

The 'uBootHWid' interface name used here is still up for debate @ https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/65678

the namespace and interface name may change in the future depending on how the discussion there goes, but this name is being used in internal test code.

Because some of the fields depends on the design,
We should wait for the design doc review https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/65678
